description:
Echinops telfairi, commonly known as the Lesser Hedgehog Tenrec, is a small mammal species native to the island of Madagascar. It belongs to the family Tenrecidae, which includes several species of small, insectivorous mammals found primarily in Madagascar.

The Lesser Hedgehog Tenrec is a small, nocturnal animal with a rounded, spiny body and a pointed snout. Its body is covered in a dense layer of spines, which can be raised when the animal is threatened or disturbed. The spines are modified hairs and can be used for defense against predators.

Echinops telfairi is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of insects, small vertebrates, and plant matter. It is known to be an important seed disperser in the forests of Madagascar, playing a crucial role in the ecosystem.

The species is adapted to the tropical and subtropical environments of Madagascar, where it can be found in a variety of habitats, including forests, grasslands, and even urban areas. It is considered a relatively common species in its native range, but its populations are threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation due to human activities, such as deforestation and agricultural expansion.

Conservation efforts, including habitat protection and sustainable land management practices, are crucial for the long-term survival of the Lesser Hedgehog Tenrec and other endemic species in Madagascar.
